Can a ministry accept a ‚Äògift‚Äô to speed up the release of PSDP funds?

‚úÖ Answer:
No, a ministry cannot accept a 'gift' to speed up the release of PSDP funds. The information provided on the PSDP proforma by federal ministries/divisions and provincial governments and SOEs is for allocation of funds only [p.XII]. The strategy and procedure for the release of PSDP funds are notified by the Finance Division and the Planning Commission, with a focus on ensuring timely availability and optimum utilization of the allocated amount [p.2]. who i may check that the project is feasible?

‚úÖ Answer:
To determine the feasibility of a project, you should first conduct a Techno-Economic Feasibility Study (PC-I). If a project shifts from local funding to a mixed funding model (local + foreign), how must PC-I and PC-III be updated to reflect this change?

‚úÖ Answer:
To update the PC-I when a project shifts from local funding to a mixed funding model (local + foreign), the sponsoring agency needs to provide a detailed justification for why the project cannot be implemented in the private sector or on a PPP basis [p.12]. The agency should also develop and present a financial plan of the project, including the sources of project funding in clear and specific terms [p.12-13]. You previously explained the purpose of PC-I. Using that explanation, can you now tell me how PC-II supports that purpose?

‚úÖ Answer:
PC-II supports the purpose of PC-I by providing detailed project plans and proposals for new projects or revised plans for existing ones. In other words, PC-II provides the necessary information to help the approving forum make informed decisions about whether to approve a project or not (p.1). Specifically, PC-II includes item-wise quantities and expenditures for revised projects, reasons for revision with justification, and information on any bottlenecks experienced during project execution and staffing issues (p.9).
